prompts.summary: Asked AI to imagine a browser-based game concept for teaching unit testing fundamentals (Red-Green-Refactor TDD cycle) to university students in a Software Quality module.
prompts.outcome: AI produced 'The Unit Testing Gauntlet' concept — three-panel layout, traffic-light TDD metaphor, 5 escalating levels from arithmetic to boss-round palindrome checker, scoring/streak system.

prompts.summary: Asked AI to implement the full game from the design concept.
prompts.outcome: All four source files generated: index.html, style.css, levels.js (5 levels x 3 phases), game.js (engine, sandbox test runner, scoring, UI). Zero external dependencies — pure HTML/CSS/JS.

prompt_strategy: Collaborative design — asked AI to imagine a browser-based game concept for teaching unit testing fundamentals (Red-Green-Refactor TDD cycle) to university students in a Software Quality module. Then asked AI to implement the full game from the design concept in a single prompt.
outcome: Complete working game implemented: index.html, style.css, levels.js (5 levels x 3 phases), game.js (engine, sandbox test runner, scoring, UI). Zero external dependencies — pure HTML/CSS/JS.
observations: AI produced full game architecture (three-panel layout, traffic-light TDD metaphor, 5 escalating levels) from a single high-level prompt. Second prompt generated all four source files with in-browser test execution sandbox, scoring/streak system, and 5 complete levels covering arithmetic, strings, arrays, conditionals, and a boss round.

methodological_notes.wakatime_vs_wallclock: WakaTime captured only ~23% of wall-clock development time (264s of ~1140s). This is because WakaTime tracks active editor interaction (keystrokes, cursor movement, file opens) but cannot observe the chat pane where the primary human-AI dialogue occurs. The AI agent wrote files directly to disk via tool calls, bypassing editor interaction entirely. WakaTime's 'AI Coding' category (14.7s) is near-zero because VS Code inline completions were not used â€” all code was generated via the agent conversation, which WakaTime cannot attribute.
methodological_notes.what_wakatime_measures: The ~4 mins of WakaTime activity represents the human's review and inspection time: opening generated files, reading through code, and editing the README. It does not reflect authoring effort.
methodological_notes.implication: Traditional developer-activity trackers (WakaTime, RescueTime) drastically undercount effort in chat-driven AI-assisted development. Wall-clock time is the more honest total measure, but WakaTime adds value as a proxy for human review involvement. Both should be recorded and reported for all artifacts.

duration_estimate_note: Session duration estimated from WakaTime active coding time plus AI interaction overhead. WakaTime recorded 4 mins 24 secs of active editor time; total session wall-clock time approx 19 mins (from first prompt at 13:33 to close at 13:52).
